text: The Historical Roots of the Reality of Extremism, Radicalism, Terrorism, and Violence. Prepared by Dr. Ali bin Abdul Aziz bin Ali Al-Shibl, Imam Muhammad bin Saud Islamic University. In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Introduction. Praise be to Allah, we praise Him, seek His help and forgiveness, and seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and our bad deeds. Whoever Allah guides, none can mislead, and whoever He misleads, none can guide. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them peace. To proceed: Allah Almighty has ordained for us this religion: Islam, and has not accepted any alternative for us: {This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islam as religion} [Al-Ma'idah: 3]. Indeed, He - Glory be to Him - does not accept from people a religion other than it: {Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam} [Al Imran: 19]. And He said: {And whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers} [Al Imran: 85].

text: This Islam is a middle religion between religions, and Muslims are truly the middle among nations, and likewise, the People of the Sunnah and the Community (Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah): the people of steadfastness are the middle among the sects of Islam. Allah said in the verse of Al-Baqarah: {And thus we have made you a just community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you} [Al-Baqarah: 143]. The middle nation are those who are upon justice and equity and upon the path of steadfastness and the Sunnah. In this research, I talk about the historical roots of the reality of extremism, radicalism, terrorism, and violence, which included an introduction, a preface, and three chapters. In the introduction, the research speech, its plan, and part of its importance in the distinction of this nation and the specificity of its religion, Islam, with justice and moderation through the path of the Sunnah and steadfastness that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, clarified for it. In the preface, defining the reality of the research terms: 1- First, regarding the meaning of extremism (Ghuluw) and its reality, and what came from the noble texts in the two revelations warning against it. 2- Second, regarding the meaning of radicalism (Tatarruf) and its reality. 3- Third, regarding the meaning of terrorism (Irhab) and its reality, and defining the contemporary term terrorism. 4- Fourth, regarding the meaning of violence ('Unf) and its divisions. 5- Fifth, regarding the relationship between extremism, radicalism, excess (Ifrat), and the like.

text: Chapter One: The meaning of extremism (Ghuluw) and its reality and clarification of some synonymous terms. The meaning of extremism by referring to linguistic sources and dictionaries, it appeared that extremism is: exceeding the limit and transgressing it. Al-Jawhari said in Al-Sahih: ((He went to extremes (Ghala) in the matter, he goes to extremes (Yaghlu) extremism (Ghuluwwan), meaning he exceeded the limit in it)). And Al-Fairuzabadi said in Al-Qamus: ((Ghala Ghala'an, so he is Ghalin (expensive/extreme) and Ghaliyyun, the opposite of cheap... and he went to extremes in the matter Ghuluwwan, he exceeded its limit)). And Al-Zubaidi agreed with him in Taj al-Arus. Ibn Manzur said in Al-Lisan: ((... The origin of Ghala' is: elevation and exceeding the measure in everything... It is said: You exaggerated (Ghalayta) the dowry of the woman, meaning you made it expensive. From it is the saying of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him: ((Do not exaggerate (La Taghalu) in the dowries of women)) and in a narration: ((Do not exaggerate (La Taghalu) in the dowry of women)). Meaning do not exaggerate in the amount of the dowry. And he went to extremes in religion and the matter, he goes to extremes, extremism: he exceeded its limit. text: The meaning of Radicalism (Tatarruf). Radicalism (Tatarruf) is Tafa'ul - with emphasis on the 'Ayn - from Tarafa Yatrufu Tarafan with movement (vowel), which is taking one of the two sides and inclining towards them: either the lower or the farthest side (1), and from it they applied it to the side and the edge of a thing. And the concept of radicalism in common usage - in this time -: Extremism in a creed, idea, doctrine, or other specific to a religion, group, or party. That is why radicalism is described to sects of Jews and Christians, so there are right-wing radical parties or left-wing radical parties. It has been described as religious, movement, and political radicalism. And describing extremism as radicalism has its justification by taking one of the two sides, as the first one said: Do not go to extremes in anything of the matter and be moderate... Both sides of the intent of matters are blameworthy. But the legal description for strictness in religion and excess in it must refer back to the Sharia itself, not people's terminology, concepts, and applications, as indicated by the hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said during Hajj: «Like these throw, and beware of excess in religion, for those before you were only destroyed by excess in religion» narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Majah, and Al-Hakim and he authenticated it. text: Defining the Term 'Contemporary Terrorism': A statement defining it was issued by the Islamic Fiqh Council of the Muslim World League in Makkah during its sixteenth session, held in Shawwal of the year 1423 AH in Makkah Al-Mukarramah. They defined terrorism with a definition that preceded many global entities that were mistaken in its meaning and implications. Their statement read: ((Terrorism is aggression practiced by individuals, groups, or states acting unjustly against human beings regarding their religion, life, intellect, wealth, and honor. It includes forms of intimidation, harm, threats, and unlawful killing, as well as acts related to banditry, highway robbery, and every act of violence or threat carried out in execution of an individual or collective criminal project aimed at instilling terror among people, or terrifying them by harming them, or exposing their lives, freedom, security, or statements to danger. Among its forms is causing damage to the environment or to any public or private facilities or properties, or exposing any national or natural resources to danger. All of this is among the forms of corruption on earth that Allah - Glory be to Him - has forbidden Muslims from committed. The Almighty said: {And do not desire corruption in the land. It is the opposite of gentleness (Rifq). It refers to severity in speech and action. The reality of violence: It is harshness in speech, opinion, action, or state! This generates what is called doctrinal violence, scientific violence, and intellectual violence in opinion, understanding, and conception?! Thus, violence is a result of excess and extremism. text: The Relationship between Excess (Ghuluw), Extremism (Tatarruf), and Exorbitance (Ifrat) and the like: Excess (Ghuluw) is, in reality, the highest rank of Exorbitance (Ifrat) generally. For example, 'Ghuluw' in a shroud means raising its price excessively and being exorbitant about it. Excess (Ghuluw) is more specific than Extremism (Tatarruf); because Extremism is crossing the limit and distancing oneself from mediation and moderation, whether by excess or negligence, or in other words: negatively or positively, by increase or decrease, whether it is Ghuluw or not. The criterion is reaching the two ends (extremes) of a matter. Ghuluw is implied in the poet's saying: 'Do not go to excess in any matter and be moderate... For both ends of intended matters are blameworthy.' Thus, Ghuluw is more specific than Extremism regarding crossing the natural limit in increase and decrease. In the case of decrease, it is called Ghuluw if one exaggerates in the decrease; it is said: 'He went to excess in decrease,' as in the Jews' aversion regarding the right of the Messiah, son of Mary, peace be upon them. Similarly in increase, if one exaggerates in it, like the Christians' excess regarding the Messiah, son of Mary. Extremism (Tatarruf): Is biasing towards the two ends of a matter, so it includes Ghuluw, but Ghuluw is more specific than it regarding increase and crossing limits, not just merely moving away from the center to the extremities. In other words: Every Ghuluw is extremism, but not every extremism is Ghuluw. The Difference between Steadfastness (Istiqamah) and (Excess, Extremism, and Terrorism):

The reason for this was that this adherence by them, may Allah be pleased with them, coincided with correct knowledge, sound understanding, and a determination eager for knowledge and insight, so they were saved from excess, let alone persisting in it. But when people became distant from the time of the virtuous ones, and religion became strange, and ignorance enveloped many Muslims, the one holding fast to the Sunnah of the Chosen One (peace be upon him), biting onto it with his molars, became an outcast and mocked in those societies.
